achievements.achievement: Namibia has also adopted the National e-Government Procurement Strategy and has implemented an e-portal as the first phases of this national e-government procurement system.

Similarly, the National eHealth Strategy 2021-2025, which is currently being implemented by the Ministry of Health cites emerging technologies such as AI as opportunities for the health system in Namibia.
The Ministry of Information and Communication Technologies has developed a national digital strategy to harmonize digitalization efforts across the country.
Recognized for its transformative potential, AI is seen as a key enabler of well-being, economic growth, and solutions to global challenges.

To support successful implementation, the OECD Digital Policy Committee developed practical guidance and established a forum for exchanging information on AI policy, encouraging multi-stakeholder and interdisciplinary dialogue.
The late President, Dr Hage Geingob, established a Presidential Task Force on the Fourth Industrial Revolution (2021-2022) tasked with assessing Namibia’s readiness for 4IR.

Recommendation guiding principles in AI legislation • To ensure that AI technologies in Namibia are developed and deployed responsibly, it is essential to safeguard fundamental human rights such as privacy, freedom of expression, and protection from discrimination by embedding transparency, accountability, and trust into all AI systems.
• AI systems must also be secure and rigorously tested, particularly those deployed in critical infrastructure, to ensure safety and resilience against cyber threats.
With the upcoming Sixth National Development Plan (NDP6), a programme results matrix (PRM) will be implemented to facilitate annual progress assessments.
In terms of linguistic preservation, AI technologies like speech recognition, machine translation, and digital archiving could support the preservation of Namibia’s Indigenous languages.

Notably, the project Food Security and Nutrition Improvement by Fostering Emerging Technologies, led by Prof Percy Chimwamurombe at the Namibia University of Science and Technology, was awarded a total of N$ 715,878.
NUST established a robotics and AI accelerator.

rankings_indices.context: Namibia was ranked as number eight (8) in Africa according to the 2024 StartupBlink Global Startup Ecosystem Index and was equally ranked 8th in sub-Saharan Africa for the Global Innovation Index indicating that the country is performing fairly.
